How to avoid a cold (this method has prevented years of colds for me):

1) Treat colds like allergies and use prevention methods

2) Leave the house when turning on central heating for the first time of the year. A change in dust, heat and humidity irritate the nasal tissue which cause drainage, drainage causes coughing, coughing and climate change irritates the throat. Put dust filters in your vents to help. Turn on a humidifier and use a barometer to keep humidity around 45-50. Use a space heater instead of central and layer your clothing.

3) When allergy season is in, cover your mouth and nose with a paper towel when walking from house to car and vice versa (especially if someone is cutting grass). If exposed to grass mold, dust, etc., do a sinus irrigation as soon as possible. Use anti-allergens on bed linens. Vacuum and dust regularly.

4) Keep hand sanitizer in your car and use it if you have to touch public doors, shopping carts, etc. Don’t touch your face! If someone in public sneezes, go the other way.

5) A probiotic can boost the immune system. Pro 15 Hyperbiotics is a good one.

I use to for a good ten years go to work during winter with my usual work T-shirt, it does get cold but I did it because distance to work wasn't long (10 minute walk) and majority of work was inside the wards where it was always kept warm. So exposure to cold isn't bad by itself, depening on temperature, wind factor and how long your outside for. As well as general exposure, for example you will feel a lot colder walking out in a field then you would in a town centre of the same temperature simply because in the field there's no surrondings be it people or buildings and vehicles that give off a bit of heat.

Nowadays I wear more when going out in winter, I travel further for my current job and also by keeping myself warm I'm keeping the muscles warm and less likely to injure myself because of that.

You miss the first reason why being exposed to cold (going outside dressed like summer, neglecting the sweater or winter coat) makes you more likely to fall sick with flu.

The body start the shivering process to produce extra eat. This automatic system is trading energy from food to get extra heat. Your body is using that energy pretty much like it would when running a marathon. The difference being which muscles are using the energy.

When you are back at school or other virus spreading location, your body is weaker from wasting so much energy shivering. The immune system is busy to destroy the toxine from excess muscle exertion and has less soldier available to fight the incoming virus and bacterias.

The race is in favor of the invaders, they multiply faster than they are eliminated. You not only sneeze from sinus infection but also have fever and feel weak from general infection all over inside the body. The shock is much worst than a normal flu virus would be.

The "key" its not being COLD, but the "thermal-shock" (suden and fast changes in body-surface temperature), this "shock" raises the permeability of cell's membrane to virus. Thats why you can get a cold in the summer by over-exposing your head to direct sun heat, or by catching a cold draft while sweating, or by entering and leaving aclimatized rooms or buildings repeatedly.

Thats why in molecular biology a thermal shock is given to bacteria when foreign dna needs to be inserted. From ice-cold to 37ºC for 30 seconds and then back to ice, and there you have a nice thermal-shock.

"A cold is caused by viruses. If there are no viruses around, you won't catch a cold. It's as simple as that"

Well. That's just not true, unproven and just an opinion.

It could very well be that vitamine-D deficiency is the main cause. The flu or a cold probably don't have a single cause. Bringing it back to just a virus is oversimplifying it. In complex systems causation is often complicated. The relation between vitamine D (lack of sunshine) and seasonal flu is supported by A LOT of research as well as practical experiences.

Viruses are highly overrated in their capacity to make us ill and medicine is not a particularly robust science. 

As for the rest of this video. It's just someone's opinion. No more, no less. Next.

In reference to the study on cold feet, 13/90 of those chilled reported cold symptoms 4-5 days after the chilling while a control group of 5/90 of those that weren't chilled reported cold symptoms. That seems to show an obvious difference and effect. However, all 18 who reported these delayed cold symptoms were reported to have had significantly more colds each year during their previous untouched lives than the 162 who did not report colds. Even the study refers to the knowledge of the common folklore of being chilled as a possible bias of REPORTING (subjectively) whether they later had cold symptoms. Perhaps a placebo effect had taken place because people simply BELIEVED and were conditioned since children that being chilled could get an individual a cold or flu. Test subjects self-diagnosed cold symptoms as nasal stuffiness, sneezing, throat irritation, and mild fever; I feel that these mild symptoms may have been exaggerated by the effect of hypochondria from conditioning bias. Something as minor as chilling of the feet (which is a body part without openings for viruses to enter the body) seems illogical to me for someone to get a cold from. Several factors: Cold and dry air makes it easier for flu and cold viruses to thrive, especially on exposed surfaces.  Which is why the virus is more likely to spread during the winter than it does during the summer.  In addition, when body temps drop, blood vessels constrict, which delays the transportation of white blood cells to the infected areas, leaving the body much more susceptible to the cold.  So when we talk about immune systems being weaker because of cold temps, it's kind of true but not entirely accurate.  Your immune system's strength is the same, the reaction just becomes slightly more delayed because of the vessel constriction; which gives the opportunity for a virus to attack faster.

I still say being outside in the cold of winter especially in cold climates does not give you a cold. I spend as much time outdoors in winter as I do in summer. I bicycle 12 miles a day 1/2 to work and 1/2 from. I stay unsick all year. I am in the sunlight (when its shining) for about an hour a day the amount of time it takes me to ride both to and from work total. But I live alone so any germs in my house are mine to begin with. I am around about a dozen people at work some who complain of being sick,having a possible cold or flu and who couch and sneeze. I still never get sick. I spend more time outdoors in summer hiking,camping a mountain biking. My nose does get stuffed up by the time I get to work in the cold air but once I warm up (usually within about 15 minutes) I am able to breathe normal again.
Because I cycle to work at 7 am when its zero to 32 degree's out I stay warm in proper winter clothing. When I cycle home in the afternoon, its warmed up to 50-60 degree's (this winter,anyway) and I strip to shorts and a tshirt and still sweat on the way home. Maybe my immune system is better than most others but I just do not get sick as long as I exercise at least one hour a day pedaling my bike about 15-20 mph. In summer I spend more time cycling and lots more time hiking and am outside probably 12-20 hours a week.

I learned in Biology that when we get cold, your body has to maintain homeostasis. In order to do that, it needs more energy than usual for certain bodily functions and sometimes shivering, but it can only make so much ATP at a time. In order to compensate, the first system it pulls the energy from is your immune system, which leaves you more susceptible to getting sick.

I agree with part of this video, but not all of it. According to Immunologists, which I have read from Medical Journals, the cold (which is a virus) can only be acquired by being exposed to the virus. So that part of the video is correct. The part I don't agree with is that if you're body temperature is colder, you are more likely to get the virus. The Immunologists stated that the cold virus actually doesn't do anything as far as they could tell, the symptoms you get are from your Immune System reacting to a virus in the body, and creating an Immune response. So the stronger your Immune System, the stronger the symptoms. So if your Immune System gets weakened, your symptoms will be weakened.

To put it simply, if the cold virus gets into your body, you will have the cold until the body can create antibodies to the virus, and then get rid of it (Unless you have already had that particular strain of cold, which would then be destroyed before symptoms occur). Nothing will make the cold go by faster.
